awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Improved Algorithms for Multiwave Imaging in Complex Media: Theory and Computation
awd_abstract_narration:
Improved imaging techniques are necessary to guide and inform increasingly complex surgical procedures.  For example, cardiac bypass surgeries are required for infants born with congenital heart defects; however, approximately 50% of children develop brain injury perioperatively, leading to the damaging complications for survivors of congenital heart disease. Improved cerebral imaging techniques are needed to evaluate the effects of surgical procedures on brain perfusion. One of the most promising techniques for cerebral imaging are multiwave imaging methods such as photo-acoustic and thermo-acoustic tomography, which combine properties of different waves to obtain high contrast and resolution unattainable by traditional modalities.  This project is motivated by the possible application of multiwave imaging to monitor cerebral blood perfusion in infants. It aims to incorporate the complexity of media properties in the head (brain, vasculature, blood, cerebrospinal fluid, skull, skin) into these imaging techniques, while making these techniques more robust to noise and uncertainty. 

The goals of this project are both theoretical and computational. The first is to identify general assumptions under which the photo-acoustic measurements render the simultaneous recovery of the internal source and the wave speed. This will be accomplished by expanding the mathematical theory concerning the simultaneous recovery of acoustic sources and media properties, which is one of the main open questions regarding photo-, thermo- and magneto- acoustic imaging. Based on preliminary work, the investigators have relaxed a-priori conditions under which simultaneous recovery is possible. The next step is to determine which conditions are essential and which ones can be removed. The second goal is computational and uses the intrinsic property of the photo-acoustic effect, which produces high contrast pressure profiles. The aim is to design novel discontinuous Galerkin methods for accurate, low dispersion simulations of high contrast pressure waves for use in new imaging algorithms. These methods are designed to achieve high performance on GPU architectures in the presence of realistic media and geometries. The third goal is to incorporate these new developments into PDE-constrained optimization algorithms, which, in addition to approximating the unknown wave speed of the medium, will also provide robustness with respect to noise and lack of information.

por.por_cntn:
Better cerebral imaging is particularly needed to avoid brain damage due to inadequate perfusion during cardiac surgery for infants born with congenital heart defects. Such surgeries require many hours of cardiopulmonary bypass for surgeons to perform the necessary repairs to the heart and main vessels. Depending on the type of surgery, from 35% to 75% of children develop brain injury perioperatively leading to long-lasting complications for survivors of congenital heart disease. This high prevalence of brain injury indicates that there is an unresolved need for better techniques to evaluate the effects of mechanical circulation on brain perfusion. This project was motivated by the potential improvements obtained from mathematical and computational models to monitor cerebral blood perfusion in infants. The project was designed as an interdisciplinary effort from a PI affiliated with Texas Children’s Hospital and the other PI at the Department of Computational and Applied Mathematics of Rice University.

One of the most promising techniques for cerebral imaging are multiwave imaging methods such as photo-acoustic and thermo-acoustic tomography, which combine properties of different waves to obtain high contrast (optical) and high resolution (ultrasound) unattainable by traditional modalities. Our goal was to understand the interplay between media properties (such as brain matter, vasculature, blood, cerebrospinal fluid, skull, skin, and ultrasonic sensors) and reconstruction algorithms to obtain blood perfusion images.

 This project had both theoretical and computational objectives. The first objective was to identify general assumptions under which the photo-acoustic measurements render the simultaneous recovery of the internal source and the wave speed. This was accomplished by expanding the mathematical theory concerning the simultaneous recovery of acoustic sources and media properties, which is one of the main open questions regarding photo-, thermo- and magneto- acoustic imaging. We have proposed new a-priori conditions under which simultaneous recovery is possible. These conditions were stated in precise mathematical terms and we rigorously proved the solvability of the joint photoacoustic problem. 

For the second objective, we investigated the role that ultrasound sensors play in the imaging process. The actual interaction between the acoustic waves and sensors has not received enough attention. Most reconstruction algorithms for photoacoustic imaging assume that the pressure field is exactly measured on a detection surface. However, actual sensors do not measure pressure exactly due to their non-uniform directional and frequency responses. This is the case for piezoelectric and optical sensors. Using the basic constitutive relations for sensor materials, we developed mathematical models for piezoelectric and Fabry-Perot transducers. The approach simultaneously models how the pressure waves induce the measurements and how the presence of the sensors affects the pressure waves. Then we analyzed whether the data gathered by piezoelectric and optical sensors lead to the mathematical solvability of the photoacoustic imaging problem. We concluded that this imaging problem is well-posed in certain normed spaces and under a geometric assumption. We also proposed iterative reconstruction algorithms that incorporate the model for ultrasound sensors.

 The third objective is computational. It takes advantage of the intrinsic physical properties of the photo-acoustic effect, which produces high contrast pressure profiles. We designed novel discontinuous Galerkin methods for accurate, low dispersion simulations of high contrast pressure waves. We developed weight-adjusted DG methods for the transmission of waves from acoustic to elastic materials to simulate the presence of the human skull. These methods are designed to achieve high performance on Graphical Processing Units architectures. We also incorporated these new developments into PDE-constrained optimization algorithms, which, in addition to approximating the unknown wave speed of the medium, also provide robustness with respect to noise and lack of information.

 Overall, this grant has partially funded the work of the PIs which is the subject of 15 peer-reviewed scientific papers, and local, national, and international conference presentations.

Regarding the broader impacts, the grant has supported the studies of a graduate student who has successfully complete a MA degree in computational and applied mathematics and has proposed his PhD thesis. So far, the student has co-authored 2 papers and is working on a third paper. Also, each year, the grant sponsored a team of undergraduate students for their senior design projects. A total of 12 students were impacted by the grant. They completed their two-semester long projects and successfully graduated with BS degrees in computational and applied mathematics. These students were introduced to the use of computational mathematics for medical applications. These projects were extremely important for the students as they experienced for the first time what it is like to be a professional engineer/mathematician. The PIs, one of whom is affiliated with Texas Children's Hospital (TCH), facilitated the students to have dedicated space at the TCH Predictive Analytics Laboratory, tour the TCH imaging facilities, and present their projects at the TCH Research Seminars. These experiences helped the students understand the impact of applied mathematics on clinical technologies.
